thread.title: Obama isn't trying to sway Supreme Court, White House says
thread.title_full: Obama isn't trying to sway Supreme Court, White House says

author: dweaver@thehill.com (Jordan Fabian)
title: Obama isn't trying to sway Supreme Court, White House says
text:
June 11, 2015, 03:19 pm Obama isn't trying to sway Supreme Court, White House says By Jordan Fabian 
President Obama is not attempting to sway the Supreme Court as it prepares a ruling that could unravel his signature healthcare law, the White House said Thursday. Obama has stepped up his defense of the Affordable Care Act just weeks before the court is expected to rule in the King v. Burwell case, which is expected to decide whether subsidies for buying insurance can be distributed through the federal exchange. ADVERTISEMENT Critics have accused the president of trying to pressure the justices to rule in his favor. White House press secretary Josh Earnest on Thursday noted it’s likely that that the justices have already made their decision, however.“In all likelihood, the decision in the case has already been reached and written,” he told reporters. Earnest said the president has made clear in his speeches defending ObamaCare that the court decision will be “made by a separate but equal branch of government.” Although the White House intensified its efforts to promote its healthcare law this week, Earnest said it’s not unusual for Obama to champion it in public.“I think the president views this as a significant achievement of his presidency; it has had an impact on millions of Americans,” he said. “Even if there are no more Supreme Court cases between now and January 2017, I would anticipate you’ll hear the president make that case at least one more time.”Obama made some of his bluntest comments to date on the case Monday, saying the Supreme Court should have never taken it up. The next day, he spoke to the Catholic Health Association, where he decried legal challenges and political attacks intended to upend the law. The president will sit down for an interview with the entertainment news program “Extra” on Thursday to make the case the law has helped save lives. The interview will be conducted by Jerry Penacoli, a TV correspondent and former actor who says ObamaCare helped him receive life-saving cancer treatment. “This is part of our sustained effort to try to use a variety of channels to communicate with the American public,” Earnest said. “This is an opportunity for the president to deliver a message about how valuable the Affordable Care Act has been” for millions of Americans.
